Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Energy Storage System Enabled Society (ESSENSE)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research. This award funds an effort to use team collective science and knowledge to build a strong collaborative culture. The planning team will engage investigators in strategic planning and potential test-beds exercises to enable revolutionary breakthroughs in electric energy storage and the power electronics integration. The project will plan a collective research effort to create innovative technological solutions and lay the foundation for achieving affordable, clean, resilient, and secure electric energy sources.

To address the technical barriers and challenges to distributed, autonomous, and modern power systems that meet national energy needs, the investigators will explore: (1) Solid State Batteries, (2) Nanocomposite Capacitors, (3) Wide-Band Gap Power Devices, and (4) Integrated Power Electronic and Electric Storage for Grid-tied Application. The plan is to organize two workshops, each lasting two days, to bring together faculty members and researchers from the partner institutions, national labs, and industry for team formation to address the targeted research and societal goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision of the ESSENS ERC is a 100% renewable energy generation-based society enabled by ubiquitous deployment of electrical energy storage. The main focus of ESSENSE is to bring diverse research teams across the US to develop a new energy storage technology, and its integration and its grid integration, to substantially reduce the cost of storage technologies and enable the ESSENS Vision. ESSENS will realize this vision through breakthroughs in fundamental research in battery material science; technological developments in power electronics; battery management systems; integration of distributed storage and grid-interaction technologies; and demonstrations of key applications in e-mobility, micro-grids, and 100% renewable energy grid testbeds. Seven institutions, three national labs and utility have come together to propose ESSENS to address the complex and challenging societal challenge of making electric energy storage a mainstream technology. Through ubiquitous energy storage systems, ESSENS explored the way energy is stored, transmitted, processed, and used to improve quality of life. To address the technical barriers and challenges to distribute, autonomous, and modern power systems that meet national energy needs, ESSENS explored the following technical areas: 1) Solid state batteries; 2) Flow batteries; 3) Wide-Band Gap (WBG) power integrated circuits; 4) Plug-and-Play(PnP) and low cost storage system through advanced power electronics; 5) Complex system modeling, control and optimization; and 6) New energy policy and market mechanism to encourage storage deployment. ESSENS plan is summarized in Figure 1 below. 

For the first time in human history, electrical energy costs may become negligible and can be made available at any time (temporal freedom) and at any location (spatial freedom). What is the societal impact of this trend? This question was carefully discussed in two NSF workshops that were organized by ESSENSE in this projecting. We agreed that this question must be addressed from technology, policy, and human-energy interaction points of view. ESSENS is a system-based center focusing on complex system and society issues when large storage is deployed. Will it dramatically increase U.S. use of electric energy? Will the grid control be more complex? Will it substantially reduce dependence on an electric grid? Will this enable many more electric energy intensive applications or human endeavors? To answer these questions, ESSENS is urgently needed. The ESSENS team includes scientists from multiple engineering disciplines, and will engage policy, human behavior and business experts to study how society and human behavior will change with this energy revolution. This creates a true convergence that would not be possible in an individual, PI-based research project.

 Further, ESSENS differentiates itself through three technology, partnership, and convergence efforts unique from other funded programs:

1)     molecular level to grid level/IoT convergence research;

2)     multiple university and national labs collaboration and team science approach; and

3)     integrated education and entrepreneurial/commercialization initiatives.

 Convergence occurs at the engineering and science levels, as the integration of storage materials and devices with power electronics creates new opportunities, including the substantial reduction or elimination of costly BMS. Existing battery technologies do not meet grid dynamics, safety and resiliency requirements, and market needs. Highly integrated and compact power electronics in a fundamentally new WBG Power IC will be developed by ESSENS. Complex system and society modeling control and optimization will address many of the key questions regarding a 100% renewable and storage society. Plug-and-play power electronics technology and advanced BMS systems are the two other key enabling technologies thrusts ESSENS will focus on. The center has identified three key testbeds to demonstrate ESSENS-developed technologies and study societal impacts. 

The final outcome of our discussions leads the team to develop a clear and focused strategic plan to be implemented over ten-year period. ESSENS used a top-down, systems approach to identify technology gaps, define specifications, and deliverables. The result is the three-plane diagram shown in Fig.2. ESSENS has identified several important technology areas to realize its vision: low-cost, utility-scale, flow battery storage systems; e-mobility systems; residential storage systems; off-grid mobile energy storage; and micro-grids. In the full proposal, inputs from industry stakeholders will be used to fine-tune the thrust areas and their technology roadmaps. These clearly-defined demonstration areas and testbeds will guide ESSENS? technology development with properly defined performance matrices such as voltage/power level, power density, energy density and efficiency, and cost targets. Fig.2 shows the proposed thrusts and their key relationships to the fundamental research, enabled technologies, and engineered systems planes. To identify the technical link between thrusts within the plane and between two planes, ESSENS also identified a number of convergence research opportunities between material scientists, electrical engineers, and sociologists. In the first six years, ESSENS envisions two generations of technology development and demonstration. The final recommendation is that a new ERC ESSENSE team was formed and led by the University of Texas at Austin by Co-PI Dr. Alex Huang. A proposal was submitted in late October 2020.
